channel.title: Scientific American - Official RSS Feed
channel.description: Science news and technology updates from Scientific American

item.title: Scientific American Launches Podcast
item.description: In this first episode, Scientific American editor-in-chief John Rennie reflects on the Korean stem cell debacle; the National Inventors Hall of Fame announces this year's inductees; and evolution defender Eugenie Scott discusses the importance of the decision in the recent Dover evolution trial. Also: hear outtakes from the CSI show you're never going to see on TV.
item.author: Scientific American

item.title: Ask the Experts: What causes ringing in the ears?
Feature Article: Dependable Software by Design
item.description: Powerful new analytical tools should help ensure the reliability of the huge computer programs that run banking, communications and other industrial systems
item.dc:subject: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
item.author: Daniel Jackson

item.title: Feature Article: The Secrets of Supervolcanoes
item.description: Four times in the past, titanic upheavals in California and Wyoming have covered much of North America under two feet of volcanic ash. Tiny crystals offer clues about the world's most devastating eruptions
item.dc:subject: EARTH SCIENCE
item.author: Ilya N. Bindeman

item.title: Insights: The Implicit Prejudice
item.description: Are you an unconscious racist? Social psychologist Mahzarin Banaji can measure the unsettling truth
item.author: Sally Lehrman

item.title: Technicalities: The Ultimate Blood Test
item.description: A pricey way to determine health risks: 250 tests at once
item.author: Philip Yam

item.title: Reviews: Favored by the Gods
item.description: If you're happy and you know it ... read these three new books on the biological and cultural roots of humanity's pursuit of happiness.
item.author: George Johnson

item.description: How one global-warming skeptic became a believer
